Topic.Title: Sept. 12th: New iPad Mini and iPhone 5

Message.Msg: . . A question if I may, of the Best. It's regarding Beta (β). nvda of course, has a beta of 1.87 As we know, by definition, the Market itself has a beta of 1.0. Individual stocks are then ranked according to how much they deviate from the macro Market (for simplicity purposes, the S&P 500 stock index). Born out of linear regression analysis, an individual stock's return in a specific period is linked to a regression analysis of the returns of the Market.(such as a stock index). A stock with a beta of 1.87 has returns that change, on average, by 1.87 the magnitude of the overall Market's returns. So when the Market's return falls by (-3.00%), the stock's return will be expected to fall by (- 5.61%) on average. Higher-beta stocks -- like nvda -- naturally tend to be more volatile -- and therefore riskier. . My question for Best relates to beta and the CEO chopping his own guidance. Let's assume that the stock has a Beta (β) of 1.87 and the CEO chops his unattainable guidance by (-10%). Does the Beta (β) multiplier apply? So the (-10%) reduction in guidance results in an expected decline in the stock price of (-18.7%). Which for nvda would be about $11.40, right? . . .

Topic.Title: Sept. 12th: New iPad Mini and iPhone 5

Rather it might be due to the fact that the CEO has worn the same black polo shirt and jeans to every PR event for like the past 15 years now. And the Market -- she is tired of it. This ain't 1999 any more, u know. Buy a tie, Jen. . .
